node.title: A question about how to get the 'EffectiveStrain'
node.bodyText:
Hi community,
I am trying to get the 'Effective Plastic Strain' in my problem.
At first, I have used the
[Auxvariables]
[EPS]
order = CONSTANT
family = MONOMIAL
[]
[]
[Auxkernels]
[eps]
type = RankTwoScalarAux
rank_two_tensor = plastic_strain
variable = EPS
scalar_type = EffectiveStrain
[]
[]

And then failed, then I checked #20979 and #23766 and realized that I should use
[Auxvariables]
[EPS]
        order = CONSTANT
        family = MONOMIAL
[]
[]
[Auxkernels]
[eps]
        type = MaterialRealAux
        property = effective_plastic_strain
        variable = EPS
[]
[]

But I got an error
*** ERROR ***
The following error occurred in the object "MOOSE Problem", of type "FEProblem".

Material property 'effective_plastic_strain', requested by 'eps' is not defined on block 0

Then I used the
[Debug]
    show_material_props = true
[]

the response shows
Active Materials:
    Subdomain:  (0)
      Material Name:       elasticity_tensor
      Property Names:      "effective_stiffness" "elasticity_tensor" 
      Material Name:       strain
      Property Names:      "deformation_gradient" "mechanical_strain" "rotation_increment" "strain_increment" 
                             "strain_rate" "total_strain" 
      Material Name:       stress
      Property Names:      "Jacobian_mult" "elastic_strain" "eqv_plastic_strain" "plastic_strain" "stress" 
                             
      Material Name:       density
      Property Names:      "density" 

    Active Face Materials:
    Subdomain:  (0)
      Material Name:       elasticity_tensor_face
      Property Names:      "effective_stiffness" "elasticity_tensor" 
      Material Name:       strain_face
      Property Names:      "deformation_gradient" "mechanical_strain" "rotation_increment" "strain_increment" 
                             "strain_rate" "total_strain" 
      Material Name:       stress_face
      Property Names:      "Jacobian_mult" "elastic_strain" "eqv_plastic_strain" "plastic_strain" "stress" 
                             
      Material Name:       density_face
      Property Names:      "density" 

Active Neighboring Materials:
    Subdomain:  (0)
      Material Name:       elasticity_tensor_neighbor
      Property Names:      "effective_stiffness" "elasticity_tensor" 
      Material Name:       strain_neighbor
      Property Names:      "deformation_gradient" "mechanical_strain" "rotation_increment" "strain_increment" 
                             "strain_rate" "total_strain" 
      Material Name:       stress_neighbor
      Property Names:      "Jacobian_mult" "elastic_strain" "eqv_plastic_strain" "plastic_strain" "stress" 
                             
      Material Name:       density_neighbor
      Property Names:      "density" 

Active Boundary Materials:
                           


*** ERROR ***
The following error occurred in the object "MOOSE Problem", of type "FEProblem".

Material property 'effective_plastic_strain', requested by 'eps' is not defined on block 0

I noticed that there is an "eqv_plastic_strain", so I tried
[Auxvariables]
[EPS]
        order = CONSTANT
        family = MONOMIAL
[]
[]
[Auxkernels]
[eps]
        type = MaterialRealAux
        property = eqv_plastic_strain
        variable = EPS
[]
[]

Although the code ran successfully, but the "eqv_plastic_strain" seems to be null in the paraview.
here is my input file:
#use kg mius mm

[Mesh]
    [TWC]
        type = AnnularMeshGenerator
        rmin = 3.5 # mm
        rmax = 5
        nt = 320
        nr = 21
    []
[]
  
[Variables]
    [disp_x]
    []
    [disp_y]
    []
[]

[AuxVariables]
    [accel_x]
    []
    [vel_x]
    []
    [accel_y]
    []
    [vel_y]
    []
    [vonmises]
        order = CONSTANT
        family = MONOMIAL
    []
    [pressure]
        order = CONSTANT
        family = MONOMIAL
    []
    [EPS]
        order = CONSTANT
        family = MONOMIAL
    []
[]

[AuxKernels]
    [accel_x]
        type = TestNewmarkTI
        variable = accel_x
        displacement = disp_x
        first = false
    []
    [vel_x]
        type = TestNewmarkTI
        variable = vel_x
        displacement = disp_x
    []
    [accel_y]
        type = TestNewmarkTI
        variable = accel_y
        displacement = disp_y
        first = false
    []
    [vel_y]
        type = TestNewmarkTI
        variable = vel_y
        displacement = disp_y
    []
    [vonmises]
        type = RankTwoScalarAux
        rank_two_tensor = stress
        variable = vonmises
        scalar_type = VonMisesStress
    []
    [pressure]
        type = RankTwoScalarAux
        rank_two_tensor = stress
        variable = pressure
        scalar_type = Hydrostatic
    []
    [eps]
        type = MaterialRealAux
        property = eqv_plastic_strain
        variable = EPS
    []
[]



[Kernels]
    [DynamicTensorMechanics]
        displacements = 'disp_x disp_y'
    []
    [inertia_x]
        type = InertialForce
        variable = disp_x
    []
    [inertia_y]
        type = InertialForce
        variable = disp_y
    []   
[]
  
[BCs]
    [Pressure]
        [outter_surface]
            boundary = 'rmax'
            function = triangle_pulse
            displacements = 'disp_x disp_y'
        []
    []
[]
  
[Functions]
    [triangle_pulse]
        #1gpa=1e9n/m^2=4e9 kg/(m*s^2)=1e9 kg/(e3e12mm*mius^2)=1e-6 kg/(mm*mius^2)
        type = PiecewiseLinear
        x = '0 0.25 0.5 5 10 20'
        y = '0 8e-6 4e-6 2e-6 1e-6 0'
    []
[]
  
[Materials]
    [elasticity_tensor]
        type = ComputeIsotropicElasticityTensor
        shear_modulus = 77.5e-6 #77.5Mpa
        poissons_ratio = 0.3
    []
    [strain]
        type = ComputeFiniteStrain
        displacements = 'disp_x disp_y'
        implicit = false
    []
    [stress]
        type = FiniteStrainPlasticMaterial
        yield_stress = '0 0.2e-6 0.8 0.2e-6'
    []
    [density]
        type = GenericConstantMaterial
        prop_names = density
        prop_values = 7.9e-6
    []
[]
  
[Executioner]
    type = Transient
    start_time = 0
    end_time = 2
    dt = 1e-3 #1e-3~6mium a step
    [TimeIntegrator]
        type = CentralDifference
        solve_type = lumped
    []
[]
  
  
[Outputs]
    exodus = true
[]
  

[Debug]
    show_material_props = true
[]

Now I have no idea what is wrong. Is the simulation from my input file generates no effective plastic strain? (but I have set the plastic constitutive model)
Thank you for your time and assistance!

Hello
Well it depends on the regime of strain for most materials. If the stresses arent high enough, you only see elastic strain. Then past a certain point you start observing plastic strain.
Can you plot the stresses and compare them to the elastic limit?
Guillaume

Hi GiudGiud,
Firstly I checked the relationship between stress levels and yield strength in the model as you suggested. The stress level in the model can reach 8e-6 (8Gpa) and stay there for some time, which is much more than the yield strength I set to 0.2e-6 (200Mpa).
After this, I checked the the "FiniteStrainPlasticMaterial" code carefully, found that the default tolerance is about 1e-8. Then I realised that it may be that the unit system I am using does not match this tolerance. I used a unit system of kg, mm, and μs, which results in stresses even on the order of Gpa being at the e-6 level, which is very close to the e-8 tolerance.
Therefore, I changed my unit system and now my problem is solved, thanks to your kind help!

node.title: Cubit Mesh
node.bodyText:
Hello,
I generated a simple mesh using Cubit containing a sphere at the center of a cubic box. Both of them have ID blocks (e.g., 0 and 1). When I solve my governing equations in the media, although I include both ID blocks in the MOOSE script, properties for one block are not considered for solvation.
Mesh generated by Cubit:
1.zip
I was wondering how I can solve this issue.
Thanks,
Mehdi

Hello
What do you mean by "not considered for solvation" ?
do you get an error?
Guillaume

Hello,
Thanks for your prompt response. I have two different ID blocks and two different variables for solving fick's equation. I need to consider one particular diffusion for each variable in each domain, which means that I have to define 4 different diffusion coefficients. For example,
D_u in block 0
D_u in block 1
D_v in block 0
D_v in block 1
When I checked the output, I found that the inner block (i.g., 0) has no value for either of the variables.

u has no value, but D_u probably does.
you can use the material property output to check
If u has no value, it s probably because the mesh is disjoint between the two domains so information cannot go through. You ll need to merge nodes on the boundary in Cubit
Thank you, I will check and come back to you.

node.title: Symmetric Cartesian Simulation
node.bodyText:
I am trying to simulate flow from a square channel onto a surface. To start I am only interested in the velocity and pressure profiles but later I will build on this to simulate some gas mixing. I am currently using a 2D plane in the middle of my pipe and simulating both sides of the flow and the results look good but take a very long time to converge in the region I am interested in. I would like to be able to cut the domain in half and only simulate half of this cross section and I would like to do so while solving in cartesian coordinates.
In my mesh I have a boundary called axis_of_symmetry and this is in the center of the channel. On this boundary I have tried INSADMomentumNoBCBC and a natural boundary condition. With either boundary condition the velocity at the center of this boundary becomes non-physical very quickly

However, when I put this simulation in cartesian coordinates I have no issues with this boundary.

In my discussion there is an error when I wrote
"However, when I put this simulation in cartesian coordinates I have no issues with this boundary."
It should have said
"However, when I put this simulation in cylindrical coordinates I have no issues with this boundary.

So 2D XY is the problem?
And 2D RZ is fine?
Yes that is correct.

in which configuration do you get the expected results?
and did you take a look at some RZ inputs for INSAD in the test folder?
why do you want to use 2D XY?  Is the system truly XY or it's just a test?
The system is truly XY. The flow channel in the system is a rectangular prism.
It must be 3D then right, because XY would be an infinite prism
Yeah, the system is 3D but not axisymmetric so to model the flow from the system. I thought it would be most appropriate to model a cross section of the flow in 2D XY.

You wont get the wall effects right  as effectively if you model a cross section you model an infinite prism.
However it may be good enough to get started.
So what are all the boundary conditions on the pipe part?
In the center it should be natural as you have symmetry right
At the top do you have dirichlet BCs for both components?
and on the wall what do you have?

Since I am mostly interested in the effects of the fluid when it hits a surface would it be more effective to model the system as a cylindrical tube while maintaining the same flow volume in RZ that exists in XYZ
On the walls I have a 0 velocity condition.

That should be fine to get started.
How do you do the outlet? Where is the fluid supposed to exit?
I see 0 dirichlet BCs on a bunch of surface.
The boundary called inlet has a half parabola as the inlet condition. It is on the top left corner of the mesh.

node.title: Accessing a coupled array's du_dot_du
node.bodyText:
I'm having some trouble accessing a coupled array's _du_dot_du variable. In my header I define
myClass.h
...
const VariableValue & _dv_dot_dv;
...

and in the source file I define
myClass.C
InputParameters myClass::validParams( ){
    ...
    params.addRequiredCoupledVariable( "v", "my docstring" );
    ...
}

myClass::myClass( const InputParameters & parameters )
    : myBaseClass( parameters ),
    ...
    _v( coupledArrayValue( "v" ) ),
    _v_dot( coupledArrayDot( "v" ) ),
    _dv_dot_dv( coupledDotDu( "v" ) ),
    ...{
}

When I run this, I get the moose error:
*** ERROR ***
Variable 'v' is of a different C++ type than you tried to fetch it as.

Hello

can you see if it runs without that one?
You would then need to implementcoupledArrayDotDu( "v" )

Sorry, I was unclear! Yes, it's the coupledDotDu that fails for me and my subroutine works without it. I mentioned looking for coupledArrayDot because I was hoping to find someone else who had tried that.
I guess I should follow what was done to implement this in Coupleable::coupledArrayVal or Coupleable::coupledArrayDot and then try and add that method to my class. Does that sound about right?

add it to Coupleable.C and then contribute it to MOOSE ;) ?
you can follow these routines. I think the regular variable coupledDotDu will also be a good inspiration

add it to Coupleable.C and then contribute it to MOOSE ;) ?

node.title: Pre Diffusing variable
node.bodyText:
Hi there,
What would be the best method to pre diffuse a random variable before the main solve starts?
Would this best be done with a multiapp system, or by setting a kernel only to be active before/after a chose time?
Are there any examples of this?
Thanks
Gillian

Hello
Both options are possible.
If the random variable is not a main system varaible for the main solve then you will have to use a multiapp.
also if in the main solve there are more variables than the diffused one, the first part with just diffusion and nothing for the other variable, you will have to be kernel to use a NullKernel for the other variables.
Guillaume

Hi Guillaume,
The method I have landed on is to just allow the diffusion to happen alongside the normal solve, as I can change the diffusion coefficient so that it happens on a time scale much shorter than that of the rest of the system.
Thank you for all your help.
Best wishes,
Gillian

node.title: Jacobians of materials with coupled variables
node.bodyText:
I have a material that is a function of various solution variables (v). I have been able to compute the Jacobians within the material property and expose the Jacobians to a kernel. This kernel however does not explicitly depend on u so when computeOffDiagJacobian is called in my kernel the Kernel doesn't update.
Because these are very general materials, I don't always know what they will be functions of. Is there a way to have my kernel add the coupled solution variables for a given material property to it's own without having to add that to the input definition?

Hello
Computing the Jacobian inside a material is not standard. It s the kernel's role to compute the Jacobian.
Did you verify that computeOffDiagJacobian is called? With some preconditioning in PFJNK it is not called unless a parameter is passed.
A kernel will not be able to modify the way a material property is being computed. The material property is pre-computed for all quadrature points when considering an element in the residual loop & jacobian loop
Guillaume

Computing the Jacobian inside a material is not standard. It s the kernel's role to compute the Jacobian.

Sometimes you have materials that are functions of solution variables though (solid mechanics has this situation). Computing the consistent tangents of those materials in the same material object would seem seem to make sense, at least to me. Maybe I'm not thinking about it the way that the MOOSE dev team does.

Did you verify that computeOffDiagJacobian is called? With some preconditioning in PFJNK it is not called unless a parameter is passed.

Yes, I have gotten it to call. A solution is just to add a call to addCoupledVar to the kernel that the user has to specify which variables were used when computing the material. That works, but I was hoping there would be something less prone to error.

A kernel will not be able to modify the way a material property is being computed. The material property is pre-computed for all quadrature points when considering an element in the residual loop & jacobian loop

I don't want the kernel to modify what the material is doing, I want a kernel that consumes a material to know that it has more dependencies that will need Jacobian contributions due to the material's dependencies.

If you use AD, it will capture that additional dependencies naturally when computeResidual is called for computing the Jacobian.
If you do not use AD, then implementing the computeOffDiagJacobian is where you need to capture all these dependencies, manually. You ll need to add the derivatives of the material properties with regards to the variables coupled in

If you use AD, it will capture that additional dependencies naturally when computeResidual is called for computing the Jacobian.

Okay, that makes sense. This is a personal preference, but I like to use hand-coded Jacobians as a form of verification. I do understand the appeal of AD though.

If you do not use AD, then implementing the computeOffDiagJacobian is where you need to capture all these dependencies, manually. You ll need to add the derivatives of the material properties with regards to the variables coupled in

Okay, that's disappointing but I understand. Thanks!

@NateAM i think it makes sense to do the derivative calculations in the material especially if you are going to use it in multiple residual objects. But as you’ve noted there is no way to get around the requirement (at least not currently) that you need the explicit coupling via addCoupledVar in order to get the off diagonal Jacobian call for that variable. Sorry for the inconvenience!

@NateAM i think it makes sense to do the derivative calculations in the material especially if you are going to use it in multiple residual objects. But as you’ve noted there is no way to get around the requirement (at least not currently) that you need the explicit coupling via addCoupledVar in order to get the off diagonal Jacobian call for that variable. Sorry for the inconvenience!

No worries! I just get so used to most things being possible here that I'm surprised when I run into something that isn't available yet!
Thinking about it during my run, this seems totally fixable. I ll raise an issue. No timeline on the fix though
That would be great @GiudGiud! I have a workaround that is fine for the present but it would be nice if there were more guardrails to keep me from messing up an input deck.

node.title: Using a SolutionUserObject with the Thermal Hydraulics Module
node.bodyText:
Hi MOOSE team,
I have encountered a problem that occurs when using a SolutionUserObject in a thermal hydraulics problem.  I am using a SolutionUserObject to read in a volumetric heating variable, aptly named vol_heating, that is calculated in another MOOSE app. I then use this term with a HeatSourceFromPowerDensity object in order to apply the heating term on my heat structure. This works perfectly fine when I do not have any flow channels defined, the heat structure heats up as expected. However, when channels are defined, I get an error of the following sort.
The following error occurred in the object "solution_in", of type "SolutionUserObject".

Failed to access the data for variable 'vol_heating' at point (x,y,z)=(       0,        0,       -5) in the 'solution_in' SolutionUserObject

The coordinate 0, 0, -5 are the starting coordinates of one of my flow channels. The SolutionUserObject is looking for the variable value on my flow channels. I understand why, but is there any way to prevent this from happening? I have tried using 'execute_on = INITIAL', but to no success. I have included some input files and a mesh which together constitute a minimum working example. The volumetric_heating input file needs to be run first so that the results can be imported in the thermal hydraulics input files with the SolutionUserObject. Running the th input file will result in the same error I mentioned above. The no_channels_th input file is almost identical, but has the flow channel removed, and runs just fine.
To summarise, I want to read in a variable that only exists on the heat structure, not the flow channels.
Any help is greatly appreciated:)
volumetric_heating.txt
no_th_channels.txt
th.txt
Mesh.zip

I ll take a look
EDIT Ignore my previous reply, wrong post
Guillaume

actually it wasnt that bad
you just need to add a block restriction
[AuxKernels]
  [aux-vol_heating]
    type = SolutionAux
    solution = solution_in
    variable = vol_heating
    from_variable = vol_heating
    scale_factor = 1e-2

    block = 'hs_geom:theblock'
  []
[]
Thanks Guillaume:)
